repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Problem: `CompleteDone` currently does not specify the reason for why completion was done, which is problematic for completion plugins as they cannot know whether the event was triggered due to the completion being canceled, accepted, or for some other reason.

Solution: Add a `reason` key to `v:event`, which is set by `CompleteDone` to indicate why completion ended.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
|CompleteDone| now sets the `reason` key in `v:event` which specifies the
reason for completion being done.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -39,6 +39,11 @@ NEW FEATURES                                                    *news-features*
 
 The following new APIs or features were added.
 
+|CompleteDone| now sets the `reason` key in `v:event` which specifies the
+reason for completion being done.
+
+See https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/20671 for more information.
+

comment_data.body:
I think this should be more explicit: _how_ is a completion accepted? (by `<c-y>`, or are there other ways?)

Same for `aborted`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -466,6 +466,14 @@ CompleteDone			After Insert mode completion is done.  Either
 				CompleteDonePre if you need it.
 				|v:completed_item| gives the completed item.
 
+				Sets these |v:event| keys:
+				    reason	Reason for completion being
+						done. Can be one of:
+						"accepted"   - completion was
+						               accepted

- "accepted": completion...
- "aborted": ...

comment_regular_data.body:
To add some context to this:


There was a discussion in chat about what could be done in core to make implementing something like https://github.com/mfussenegger/nvim-lsp-compl easier

One low hanging fruit seemed to add a reason to the `CompleteDone` event. Use-cases:


- LSP completion candidates can be incomplete. E.g. you've something like `h<trigger-completion>` and get back 20 candidates, + an indication that there are more available. You'd show these 20 candidates via `complete()`, after the user types another character you'd fetch more candidates and call `complete()` again. Currently calling `complete()` again triggers a `CompleteDone` event. This is problematic because:

- LSP completion items can contain snippets. A plugin will want to expand the snippet in a `CompleteDone` event, but not always. Cases where you don't want that:

  - Subsequent `complete()` calls as described above
  - If the user aborts the completion (`ctrl-e`)
  - If the user types characters that end the completion due to no more match (instead of accepting via `ctrl-y`). E.g. You type `h<trigger-completion>` and candidates are `ha` and `ho` but you type `u`. Or you type `hal`.

  Currently plugins can handle that by setting some flags to indicate that the next `CompleteDone` event is to be ignored. It would be easier if there were a `reason` in the `CompleteDone` event.


I think to handle this at least 3 reasons are required:

- `accept` (`ctrl-y`)
- `cancel` (`ctrl-e` or another `complete()` call)
- `exhausted` (typed characters not matching completion candidates)
Looks reasonable; rebase and just stick to the three reasons @mfussenegger lists -- can always add more later, if and when they become useful.  @zeertzjq ?

> To add some context to this:
> 
> There was a discussion in chat about what could be done in core to make implementing something like https://github.com/mfussenegger/nvim-lsp-compl easier
> 
> One low hanging fruit seemed to add a reason to the `CompleteDone` event. Use-cases:
> 
> * LSP completion candidates can be incomplete. E.g. you've something like `h<trigger-completion>` and get back 20 candidates, + an indication that there are more available. You'd show these 20 candidates via `complete()`, after the user types another character you'd fetch more candidates and call `complete()` again. Currently calling `complete()` again triggers a `CompleteDone` event. This is problematic because:
> * LSP completion items can contain snippets. A plugin will want to expand the snippet in a `CompleteDone` event, but not always. Cases where you don't want that:
>   
>   * Subsequent `complete()` calls as described above
>   * If the user aborts the completion (`ctrl-e`)
>   * If the user types characters that end the completion due to no more match (instead of accepting via `ctrl-y`). E.g. You type `h<trigger-completion>` and candidates are `ha` and `ho` but you type `u`. Or you type `hal`.
>   
>   Currently plugins can handle that by setting some flags to indicate that the next `CompleteDone` event is to be ignored. It would be easier if there were a `reason` in the `CompleteDone` event.
> 
> I think to handle this at least 3 reasons are required:
> 
> * `accept` (`ctrl-y`)
> * `cancel` (`ctrl-e` or another `complete()` call)
> * `exhausted` (typed characters not matching completion candidates)

As `CompleteDone` is not called on exhaustion, I only implemented `accepted` and `canceled` for now. Whether `CompleteDone` should be called for exhaustion or not is something that needs further discussion, and should not block this PR. Ref: #28558
Should it be `canceled` or `cancelled`? `cancelled` is much more common in existing docs.

> or `aborted` ;)

I like `aborted` more so I picked that

title: feat(complete): specify reason for CompleteDone
